ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: More advanced vocab and grammar structures, with specific topical focusses. There seemed to be a high level of focus on written and formal communication skills. Less focus on Chinese for casual settings or media.
A greater knowledge of formal written Chinese and the colloquial equivalents

I learned more about how to speak and have conversations about Chinese popular culture and social change, such as online dating, the city of Yiwu in Zhejiang, etc. Additionally, 158 had a bigger focus on using more formal structures of grammar than we were previously taught, so there was a large emphasis on using certain grammar structures.
Advanced Chinese speaking, listening, reading, and writing

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Zhou Lao Shi is an excellent teacher. The textbook is well-organized, and the class is run like a tight ship. It was usually pretty clear what the expectations and assignments were. However, the downside of all this organization was the very limited amount of time devoted to developing spoken/casual Chinese. I don't think practicing formal grammar patterns out loud counts towards this. I understand this stuff is useful if you want to go into formal/business settings, but I wish there was a much stronger focus on developing everyday Chinese vocabulary. This would be useful for reading certain kinds of modern Chinese literature as well. And also from having spent time in China, understanding Chinese people is an area of huge difficulty. There was almost no practice on that. Finally, this class is so organized that it becomes very easy to figure out how to get good grades without too much effort. It felt like many homework assignments required way too much time (like 3hrs between many classes), yet the payoff in learning was limited because the assignments were too easy or repetitive. The same goes for testsI thought they made it too easy to cram/use notes, and I didn't feel forced to really learn the material well.

Strengths: Very engaging class, interesting topics that increase your Chinese level 
Weaknesses: Too many vocab words every night, makes it hard to retain vocab
The course moved so so quickly.
Strengths: Zhou Laoshi is a very caring professor who is very considerate of his students and is always willing to hear you out if you have concerns.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I mean you pretty much have to take it to move onto electives, unless you do a Light. I don't think it was my most productive semester of Chinese learning by any means. If you have the option and it makes sense in other ways, just do a Light. I think I would have benefitted a lot more if I was learning this material while being surrounded by a Chinese language environment.
Yes, I've noticed such an improvement in my ability to understend authentic chinese content like news articles and tv shows.
Yes. After 150 and 151 this course is refreshing and isn't as full of tedious memorization and allows you to just learn more Chinese with less stress.
Yes absolutely if you're looking to improve your Chinese
